title: 108_hr4136
content: The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 combines the Hope and Lifetime Learning Credits under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows individuals to claim a tax credit for 50% of qualified education expenses up to $3,000 per year. Qualified expenses include higher education expenses and job skill improvement courses at eligible institutions. Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to reflect these changes. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified education expenses. Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to make conforming and clerical changes to various provisions. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 amends Section 221(d) of the Internal Revenue Code to define an "eligible student" as someone who meets certain requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to coordinate with education credits and qualified tuition programs. This includes changes to sections 529, 530, 6050S, and 6213. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 amends section 25A in the Internal Revenue Code by replacing "section 25A(g)(1)" with "section 25A(f)(1)". The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 amends section 25A in the Internal Revenue Code to apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. It also establishes a uniform definition of qualifying higher education expenses. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 updates the definition of qualified higher education expenses to include tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and special needs services for eligible students. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 expands qualified higher education expenses to include reasonable costs for room and board incurred by eligible students while attending an institution. The amount for room and board expenses should not exceed a certain limit. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows for room and board expenses to be included in qualified higher education expenses, with a limit set by the eligible educational institution or the actual invoice amount for students residing in university housing. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows eligible students to include room and board costs charged by the educational institution in their qualified higher education expenses. Eligible students must meet certain requirements and be enrolled at least half-time. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows eligible students to include room and board costs in their qualified higher education expenses if they are enrolled at least half-time and carrying a normal full-time workload for their course of study. Exceptions include expenses for sports, games, hobbies, student activity fees, athletic fees, insurance expenses, and other unrelated expenses. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 allows students to include room and board costs in qualified higher education expenses. Amendments to the tax code replace "qualified tuition and related expenses" with "qualified higher education expenses" and define it as expenses required for enrollment or attendance of the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 expands qualified higher education expenses to include room and board costs. Amendments to the tax code redefine expenses for enrollment or attendance at eligible educational institutions. The Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 broadens qualified higher education expenses to cover room and board costs, amending the tax code to redefine expenses for enrollment or attendance at eligible educational institutions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is also amended to replace "qualified tuition and related expenses" with "qualified higher education expenses" in various sections. The tax code is amended to include room and board expenses for full-time students as qualified higher education expenses. The heading for section 222 is changed to "HIGHER EDUCATION." The tax code is amended to include room and board expenses for full-time students as qualified higher education expenses. The table of sections is updated to reflect this change. The tax code is amended to include room and board expenses for full-time students as qualified higher education expenses, effective for payments made after December 31, 2003.
